title: What is the worst book you've ever read from a well respected author? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most of Phillip Roth’s books. He is the most over-rated American writer of the 20th century. So repetitive, so fixated on female anatomy, so narrow in scope. Lop off “Goodbye Columbus,” “Portnoy’s Complaint” (neither of which has aged well) and a few others and what have you got? The same old complaint: He cannot get along with women. That’s half the human race. Does he respect women? No. He always see himself as the victim. I say, “he” because every book is about Phillip Roth. Roth’s “The Dying Animal” is a good example: “It tells the story of senior literature professor David Kepesh, renowned for his literature-themed radio show. Kepesh is finally destroyed by his inability to comprehend emotional commitment.” Other examples of awful work: The Breast. Protagonist, David Kepesh, becomes a 155-pound breast.My Life as a Man. “Roth introduces his most important character, the Roth-like novelist Nathan Zuckerman -- so central to Roth's vision that he'll show up in nine other books. And it's in "My Life" that Roth struggles to make sense of the spectacularly failed relationship that surely helps explain what is often cited as the major flaw in his fiction: his inability to see women whole.”The Humbling (if only!). “Brief to a fault at 140 generously spaced pages, it can hardly be called a novel at all; it is more an old man's sexual fantasy dressed up in the garb of literature.”

What is the worst book you've ever read from a well respected author? Three Stephen King novels stick out for me. I was a big fan of Stephen King (maybe I will be again someday), but after he joined Twitter I really started to dislike him. I read all three of these after that, but I have enjoyed other books of his so I don’t think that was the problem with these books: The Regulators (The Regulators (novel) - Wikipedia) Duma Key (Duma Key - Wikipedia) Lisey’s Story (Lisey's Story - Wikipedia) I couldn’t finish any of these three books. Boring, repetitive and annoying. When I’m not enjoying a book I always try and think why the author wrote it; what was the point. As a struggling writer myself, I know that when you sit down to write, especially something as long as a novel, the idea really has to grip you and keep you enthralled yourself. It has to push you forward. For the life of me I can’t see what happened with these three, why he wrote them, or why they were published…

Reading John Steinbeck’s early work answered a big question I had: Do great writers just arrive great? Or do they become great writers? The answer, I am pretty sure, is the second. John Steinbeck’s early novels pretty much suck. I finished To A God Unknown and thought to myself: “Hell, even I could write a better book than this.” This is gratifying to me, good news. It means you may start off with weak, flabby muscles but over time you can figure out how to strengthen your weaknesses and find better routes to strength. It means nobody needs to give up cuz their first effort sucks — or even their second. If Steinbeck had given up after The Long Valley or To A God Unknown the world would literally be a different place. We would have missed out on some of the greatest American fiction ever written. To a God Unknown - Wikipedia

The Bluest Eye by Toni Morrison. There's so much wrong with this book- its vast imperfections make it shocking that it's gained a loyal fan base and that it's ranked as second in Toni Morrison's oeuvre only to the vastly superior Beloved. Let me tell you why. It relies on shock factor alone. Many readers take this as a moving testament to the suffering of black people. What they fail to realise is that its only appeal to readers is blinding people of its faults through ceaseless child abuse, rape and murder. It's fine ( in fact, I condone it) to include harsh elements to your writing, but where do you stop?The symbolisis is heavy. Does she presume her readers are idiots? That we can't pick up on imagery unless she spoon-feeds it to us? Her style matured, and her ideas on such topics improved, but, seriously, why doesn't everyone else see this simple fact?Characterisation is banal. Does she Cate if what she writes is vacuous? Perhaps she was impatient, but does that justify it? And to compare that to the baby in Beloved…Be persuaded by this, because it's time critics moved on to praise her other stuff. Why this was ranked above her 2008 masterpiece remains a mystery to me…

Money, by Martin Amis, one of the very few books I have given up on without finishing. It is the only Martin Amis book I have tried, on the basis that he is a well-respected author. It is not that I object to an anti-hero protagonist; I was getting both bored and revolted simultaneously. Slightly different: I have read two books, very different from one another, by John Williams: Stoner and Augustus. These are great. But I struggled and did not finish Butcher’s Crossing; I guess I should try again.

I don’t know if E. L. James, the author of Fifty Shades of Grey, would be considered “well respected,” but when the book first came out I wanted to see what the buzz was all about. I read a few randomly selected pages from it in our local bookstore and I can honestly say it is the most poorly written bestselling book I have ever read.

There are so many! I love Robin Hobb’s early Farseer and Liveship books…they were truly inspired IMO. But by the time she got to The Rain Wild Chronicles — which take place in the same world — I was thinking “Did she have a stroke? Did someone else write these? What the hell happened…?!” They are really, really bad. I’m mostly in awe of E.O. Wilson, but his Consilience was a failure IMO. Frank Herbert completely floored me with the Dune saga, but for me God Emperor of Dune was strangely weak. For me it was pretty throw-away. The other books in the series seems much more thoughtfully written IMO. I look back on my own writing, and find some of it painful to revisit. So I empathize with authors who miss the mark on occasion. Hopefully, they recognize what didn’t work, and learn from it. My 2 cents.

Catcher In The Rye by J. D. Salinger. I have no idea why this is considered a “great American Novel”! It is non-linear, the syntax of the sentence structures are terrible, it’s juvenile in it’s commentary on sex, and has a terrible ending.

There have been several books by well-respected authors I have hated, but I don’t know if I should blame the author or me, or the place in life I was at the time I picked up the book. I did struggle to read Twilight, and when the vampire sparkled in the sunlight I threw the book across the room.

Ruth Rendall translates well to TV but the books are full of POV changes that don’t tell you who is the POV until two paragraphs in, and loose plot threads that don’t go anywhere. I struggled through one and got about 10% of the way into a second before I gave up in disgust. (I didn’t have a lot of choice of books at the time.) For just bad writing, I’ve spent about an hour going back over Facebook for these quotes and I realize that I carefully omitted the book name. It’s a Scarpetta novel by Patricia Cornwall, but I can’t remember which one. Plumbing above and below me groaned, and one by one other rooms went bright as sharp tattoos from ranges I could not see riddled the dawn. -- I don't expect a test in parsing from the first paragraph of a book. "..." he said of my forensic scientist colleague from Knoxville. -- that would be ugly even if it wasn't inserted a third of a page after the person in question had first been mentioned. It's all explained again when we meet him in the next chapter, when we find that... He was a small man with prepossessed eyes -- who had them before?

The unedited version of “Moby Dick”. By Herman Melville. I read the edited edition while in high school. It was tolerable but I didn’t want to read it again. Managed to avoid as an undergrad but going for an advanced degree there it was again. This time the unedited version. Chapter after chapter about different parts of the whales body. I thought it would never end.

The Number of the Beast by Robert Heinlein was (IMO) the worst book he wrote. Most of Heinleins later books are not as good as his early/mid books, in my opinion, but I've enjoyed many of them. Sadly, while I did finish The Number of the Beast, it was a chore…horrible.
East of Eden. Not one likable character in the entire book

Terrorist by John Updike. At the time of its publishing, Updike was 74 yrs old writing about the fictitious experience of a Muslim teenager, if you can believe it. Nobody in the novel sparked even the least bit of empathy. I got the feeling it was more a protest against the direction America was headed at the time rather than an attempt at telling a story.
I could name a number of Stephen King novels I suppose but that would be too easy. So I’ll go with The Corrections, by Franzen. Gawd, that was a slog.
Probably anything by Agatha Christie. I think her books are boring and EXTREMELY predictable. nervousnerdblog.com
